data.message: I completely disagree ... Github is not a bug tracking or issue reporting or support system ... Maybe find a way to integrate Github issues with other ticketing systems or anything similar ...
Ahmad Alfy I think Github issues are a de facto way of communicating with Open Source Project maintainers, and it is the first place anyone checks before using a new open source project or library.
Before that you had to use mailing lists or forums or IRC channels or Bugzilla which is an overkill for most projects

from my point of view  Github is "a project"  and users are going to ask for more features or some enhancements. its not about if Github is a bug tracking or not.
Maybe they think in that way: "why would i keep using your software if it's not provide me features that keeps me satisfied." and then they may move to GitLab
I agree with Ahmad Alfy. I completely disagree with this letter.
It seems that the writers of this letter are trying to introduce some  "centralization" features into a system that is "distributed" by design!
I only relate to the "content-less comments" problem, but I don't like the proposed solution.

Everyone seems to focus on the ticking and issues aspect, completely ignoring one serious problem. PRs and contributor guidelines. If we'd have an OSS hub, I'd actually appreciate if they solved this problem. 

After all, open source software is only as successful as its community of contributors, if i'm maintaining a project and have to go through highs and lows reviewing PRs that aren't following the project's contribution guidelines i'll certainly burn out.
